newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.

text.p: After a very cool reaction to the new 25 basis points fresh rate cut, Spanish government bonds climbed on Tuesday afternoon pulled higher by foreign markets.
But at the end of the day bonos underperformed Bunds, with the 10-year spread widening a bit, toward 100 basis points.
"The market is still very strong. I'm thinking it's only a bit more cautious than others. Tomorrow I'm expecting it to at least maintain today's gains," a dealer in Madrid said.
Earlier on Tuesday. the Bank of Spain sanctioned its third rate cut of the year. "That's discounted. Maybe some people were disappointed because it could have done more," a dealer added.
"Fundamentals are doing fine. The risk here is to suffer by other markets' movements," a dealer in Madrid said.
After the rate cut, Spain's yield curve flattened, with the two- to ten-year spread tightening to around 129 basis points from 136 bps before the rate decision.
But dealers expect that the market could soon resume a rising trend on expectations of other official rate cuts.
On Wednesday, the one-year bill yields are expected to fall sharply at an auction to around 5.30 percent from 5.59 percent at the previous sale on April 2, dealers added.
